title: What next for David Haye? Five possible fights after crushing defeat against Tony Bellew
text:
What next for David Haye? Five possible fights after crushing defeat against Tony Bellew The Hayemaker injured himself in the sixth round before the Bomber forced an 11th round stoppage Share Haye struggles to the ropes after injuring his right ankle (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
David Haye suffered a career-threatening defeat against Tony Bellew , who stopped the Hayemaker in the 11th round to cast doubt on his career. 
Haye rolled his right ankle and appears to have sustained severe damage to his Achilles, but he confirmed his desire to return - ideally against the Bomber. 
"I have to take my hat off to Tony Bellew. He was the better champion," Haye said. "He has bigger balls than me. You done me. I’d love to do it again. 
"I’ve never been in a fight like that before. If the fans would want to do it again." 
Here, we look at five possible opponents for his return to the ring. Tony Bellew shakes hands with David Haye after his 11th round TKO (Photo: Getty) Haye is knocked down against Bellew (Photo: REUTERS) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Mirror boxing correspondent David Anderson give his ringside verdict on Haye vs Bellew Share this video Watch Next Tony Bellew 
Haye will be badly craving the rematch, yet he is in no position to demand it. Bellew has already confirmed he is open to doing it again though. 
"So much respect for David as a fighter," the Liverpudlian said. "We can do it again!" 
Haye concedes he would have to travel, potentially to Manchester or Liverpool, to make this happen, not to mention taking much less money. But redemption is priceless and if he can avoid injuring himself again, he could very well win the rematch. 
After all, before the injury in the sixth round, Haye was winning this fight despite his lack of accuracy due to loading up too much on his power shots. Tony Bellew celebrates winning the fight (Photo: REUTERS) Anthony Joshua 
This was the end goal for Haye and his dream fight: combining a shot at a World title, AJ's IBF strap, with the fame, fortune and, let's be honest, smugness of derailing the hype train and damaging Eddie Hearn's golden boy. 
This match-up is potentially in tatters now though, but Bellew may opt to go elsewhere - which is possible after the Liverpudlian called out Deontay Wilder. 
AJ would struggle to find an opponent who could match Haye for star power and PPV buys and having already captured the World title, record-breaking purses and wider public attention resonate with the former Olympian. 
The Bellew defeat could be put down to the injury in the promotional spin and, let's be honest, there are multiple opponents on AJ's record with far less credit than Haye who have been sold as part of PPV cards. Anthony Joshua vs David Haye could break all records for a British fight (Photo: Getty) Dillian Whyte 
A fellow Londoner who likes to talk the talk: the Body Snatcher is on the fringe of world level. 
Should Haye want to stay relevant and continue to climb the rankings, as well as remain in the public eye, Whyte is a good opponent coming off an injury. 
His style would mesh with Haye's and his No.4 ranking with the WBC would immediately propel Haye back into contention for World honours to face champion Deontay Wilder. Dillian Whyte (left) celebrates beating Dereck Chisora (Photo: PA) Wladimir Klitschko 
This could well happen if Dr Steelhammer suffers defeat to Anthony Joshua next month. 
Both men have experienced the big pay day and will be reluctant to walk away from the limelight, so a rematch from their 2011 meeting would not be a total shock. 
A loser faces retirement-style match could develop later in the year with both needing lengthy spells off. Neither fighter would likely be prepared to gradually climb their way back up the rankings given their age, so this fight could be a way to salvage their careers. Joshua and Klitschko pose to promote their super fight at Wembley (Photo: Bongarts) Joseph Parker 
This is potentially a very easy match to make, as Haye was ranked No.1 by the WBO before the Bellew fight. So Haye could be in contention to be the New Zealander's mandatory challenger somewhere down the line. 
Haye would have to accept a mandatory terms and the short end of any purse split - 17 percent if left to purse bids - but he is in no position to be a diva in negotiations. 
Parker has shown a willingness to travel to the UK in the past and Haye can offer the profile the Kiwi might crave to break through as a global star. Instagram Retirement 
The cold truth of the matter is that Haye's injury could be career-threatening - so retirement is an option as he faces the undefeated father time. 
After soldiering on for six rounds and evidently grimacing simply standing on his right ankle, Haye may have done severe damage to his right Achilles. 
At 36 years old, does he have the fight and the battle to overcome a lengthy period of rehabilitation? Maybe not. Haye is knocked down by Bellew (Photo: REUTERS) poll loading Will Tony Bellew give David Haye a rematch? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
